examples.en: There was a person selling pictures on the street.
examples.ja: 道に絵を売る人がいました。

examples.en: How much would you sell this motorcycle for?
examples.ja: このバイク、いくらだったら売ってくれますか？

examples.en: I won't sell my heart for money.
examples.ja: 私の心はお金じゃ売らないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sell</kanji>, and this is a transitive verb meaning <vocabulary>to sell something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to sell something</vocabulary>, but what? What can you sell that will take the least amount of work? <reading>U</reading>ni (う)! They're just hanging out in the ocean, ready for the taking. Go scoop some up, watch out for the pointy bits, and sell them for some quick cash!

examples.en: I bought a heart-shaped balloon.
examples.ja: ハート形の風船を買いました。

examples.en: This is a heart-shaped stone for nail art.
examples.ja: これは、ネイルアート用のハート形のストーンです。

examples.en: My grandmother is good at making heart-shaped rice balls.
examples.ja: うちのおばあちゃんは、ハート形のおにぎりを作るのが上手です。

meaning_mnemonic:
ハート is of course "heart" and you know that 形 means <kanji>shape</kanji>. You've probably already figured this one out. It's <vocabulary>heart shaped</vocabulary>. 

You can add this kanji to all sorts of other things too to say "____ shaped." Give it a try!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion uses the kun'yomi reading. This is kind of like the reading you already learned for 形 just without the ち part. And rendaku happens too, so it becomes がた. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this reading too!

examples.en: First, please look at the table of contents of the book.
examples.ja: 先ず、本の目次を見て下さい。

examples.en: Even just looking at the table of contents tells you a little about the book.
examples.ja: 目次を見るだけでも、本の中について少し分かりますよ。

examples.en: Next is a page for the table of contents.
examples.ja: 次は、目次のページです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>eye</kanji> is on what's <kanji>next</kanji>. How is this possible to see what's coming up? That's because you're looking at a <vocabulary>table of contents</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That night the stars were really pretty.
examples.ja: 夜には、星がとてもきれいでした。

examples.en: A beautiful starry sky stretches over Aomori.
examples.ja: 青森には美しい星空が広がっています。

examples.en: Fruits cut into heart and star shapes are cute, and popular with children.
examples.ja: フルーツをハート形や星形に切るとかわいいし、小さい子にも人気ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Did you know the Aries cluster of <vocabulary>star</vocabulary>s used to be called the <reading>Hoe Shee</reading>p (ほし) constellation? Nah, I'm only messing, but Aries is represented by a ram and actually looks a little like a hoe. And hey, "hoe sheep" sounds like ほし. So, you know, don't let the truth get in the way of a good story.

examples.en: The color of the sea was emerald green.
examples.ja: その海の色はエメラルドグリーンでした。

examples.en: I plan to go to the sea with my friends during the summer vacation.
examples.ja: 夏休みに友人たちと海に行く予定です。

examples.en: Someday, I want to live near the sea.
examples.ja: いつか、海の近くに住みたいなぁ。

examples.en: Is WaniKani a sea creature? Is it a river creature?
examples.ja: ワニカニは海の生物なのでしょうか？川の生物なのでしょうか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You visit the <vocabulary>sea</vocabulary>. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "<reading>um, me</reading>?" (うみ). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.

examples.en: Is salmon a saltwater fish? Or is it a freshwater fish?
examples.ja: サケは海魚ですか？それとも川魚ですか？

examples.en: Can sea fish be pets?
examples.ja: 海魚はペットに出来ますか？

examples.en: If you go into the sea by scuba diving, you can see various sea fish and jellyfish.
examples.ja: スキューバダイビングで海の中に行くと、色々な海魚やクラゲを見ることができます。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>ocean</kanji> <kanji>fish</kanji> is simply an <vocabulary>ocean fish</vocabulary>. They also happen to be the most delicious kind of fish.

海魚 is often used in contrast with 川魚 (river fish), especially when talking about fish as food.
reading_mnemonic: You might think this is all going to be on'yomi, which it can be, but we'd actually like you to focus on the kun'yomi reading うみざかな here. Using the on'yomi is also correct, but sounds formal and scientific, while うみざかな is much more colloquial, so try to remember this reading instead! You already know the individual kun'yomi readings for this, but do watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: Many residents in this town are grandmas and grandpas.
examples.ja: この町の住民は、おばあちゃんとおじいちゃんが多いです。

examples.en: I want to have a pizza party with the residents of the apartment.
examples.ja: アパートの住民たちで、ピザパーティをしたいんです。

examples.en: Many residents lost their homes in the 2011 tsunami.
examples.ja: ２０１１年のつなみでは多くの住民が家を失いました。

meaning_mnemonic: They <kanji>dwell</kanji> here, these <kanji>people</kanji>. So what are they? They’re <vocabulary>residents</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There are many students in this lab every time.
examples.ja: この研究室には毎回たくさんの学生がいます。

examples.en: We plan to conduct a new chemical experiment in the laboratory tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日、研究室で新しい化学実験を行う予定です。

examples.en: This hamster was born in the lab.
examples.ja: このハムスターは研究室で生まれました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 研究 means "research"? Well the <kanji>room</kanji> where you do research is a <vocabulary>laboratory</vocabulary>!

研究室 refers to a <vocabulary>lab room</vocabulary>, often within a larger institution like a university or college.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Shall we talk about the matter later?
examples.ja: その事については、後でまたゆっくり話しませんか。

examples.en: I only understood half of what the teacher was saying.
examples.ja: 先生が言ってる事は半分しか分かりませんでした。

examples.en: I go to work by car more often than I walk.
examples.ja: 車で会社に行く事が歩いて行く事よりも多いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

As a vocab word on its own, 事 usually refers to an intangible or abstract <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>, like いい事 (good thing) or する事 (things to do). 

Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>matter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>occurrence</vocabulary>, like 大切な事 (important matter) or きのうの事 (what happened yesterday).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You've done all kinds of <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>s in your <reading>coat</reading> (こと). If you think about it, you only wear a coat when you have things to do. Try to remember all the things you've done in a coat. It's a lot! Symbolically, your coat = all the things and <vocabulary>occurrence</vocabulary>s you've experienced, and all the <vocabulary>matter</vocabulary>s you've had to deal with in life.

examples.en: On that day, I have important errands.
examples.ja: その日、大切な用事があります。

examples.en: Oh, Tanaka-sensei. What business brings you to Don Quijote?
examples.ja: あっ、田中先生。ドン・キホーテに一体何の用事ですか？

examples.en: Excuse me. I'm sorry to leave early, but I just remembered there's something I have to do.
examples.ja: すみません。用事を思い出したので、お先に失礼します。

meaning_mnemonic:
If there's a <kanji>task</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji>, then there's something you have to do, a.k.a. a <vocabulary>task</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>errand</vocabulary>.

用事 generally refers to tasks that you personally need to take care of. Often that means errands like buying groceries or paying bills. It could also mean a doctor's appointment, meeting with a friend, or work tasks like attending a meeting and finishing an assignment. It's anything on your list of <vocabulary>things to do</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The construction is from today to tomorrow.
examples.ja: 工事は今日から明日までです。

examples.en: This road is under construction now, so please take a left.
examples.ja: この道は今工事中なので、左に行って下さい。

examples.en: I couldn't sleep because of the noise of the construction last night.
examples.ja: 夕べは工事の音がうるさくて、ねむれませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Construction</kanji> <kanji>occurrences</kanji> are just different kinds of <vocabulary>construction</vocabulary>!

工事 often refers to <vocabulary>construction work</vocabulary>, especially for buildings, roads, and other infrastructure projects. But it can also cover repairs, upgrades, and installations of things like electrical systems, plumbing, phone lines, and internet as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is important to say "thank you" properly.
examples.ja: きちんと「ありがとう」と言うことは大事です。

examples.en: I lost an important notebook.
examples.ja: 大事なノートを失ってしまった。

examples.en: I have an important exam tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は大事なテストがあるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And if something is a  <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>matter</kanji> to someone, it must be a very <vocabulary>important</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> thing to them.

大事 describes something that holds great importance or value. For example, you can use 大事 to describe something or someone that matters a lot to you. You can also use 大事 to describe a crucial task or moment. And if you want to bring up a serious topic, you may say that you have something 大事 to talk about.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Nothing in your life is as <vocabulary>important</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> to you as <reading>dye</reading>s (だい). You really just love dyes more than anything else. Dyes, dyes, dyes!

examples.en: Today, I didn't get a reply to my email.
examples.ja: 今日は、メールの返事が来なかった。

examples.en: Would you like to give me a little more time? I want to think it over before I respond.
examples.ja: もう少し時間をくれませんか？返事をする前によく考えたいんです。

examples.en: There has been no response to my proposal for over a year, what should I do?
examples.ja: プロポーズの返事が一年以上ないんですが、どうしたらいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And if you <kanji>return</kanji> the <kanji>matter</kanji> to another person, you're giving a <vocabulary>reply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>response</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Three meals a day is not enough.
examples.ja: 一日に三回の食事では足りないんですよ。

examples.en: I'm having a meal now, so I'll call again later.
examples.ja: 今食事中なので、後でまた電話しますね。

examples.en: If you can only eat the same meal for the rest of your life, what would you like?
examples.ja: もし人生で毎回同じ食事しか出来ないとしたら、何がいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
A regular <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is also known as a <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>. 

食事 can refer to a specific meal, like breakfast, lunch, or dinner. It can also mean your overall <vocabulary>diet</vocabulary>, like the kinds of foods you usually eat. 食事 can even be a verbal noun for the act of <vocabulary>dining</vocabulary>, so 食事する can be used to talk about having a meal.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We use electricity every day.
examples.ja: 私たちは、毎日電気を使います。

examples.en: Use all of the conjugation forms you know to create a sentence.
examples.ja: 知っている活用形を全て使って文を作って下さい。

examples.en: Today, I want to make a pie using apples from Aomori Prefecture.
examples.ja: 今日は青森県のリンゴを使ってパイを作りたいと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>use</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary>. If you're talking about money, this can also mean <vocabulary>to spend</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<reading>Two car</reading>s (つか), are what you have <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary> because you're so huge you don't fit into one. You've got a British car on your left and an American car on your right, and you're driving them both at the same time.

examples.en: To send a letter, you use tools like a pen or paper.
examples.ja: 手紙を送るには、ペンや紙などの道具を使います。

examples.en: It is a tool for scientific experiments.
examples.ja: それは科学実験のための道具です。

examples.en: Do you have all the tools that you need for tomorrow's construction?
examples.ja: 明日の工事に必要な道具は全て有りますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tool</kanji>s you use on the <kanji>road</kanji> of life are important to have. What is your most important <vocabulary>tool</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: To get cheap furniture in Japan, I recommend IKEA or Nitori.
examples.ja: 日本で安い家具を手に入れるには、「イケア」か「ニトリ」がおすすめです。

examples.en: The entrance is small, so I'm not sure if large furniture can fit.
examples.ja: 入り口が小さいので、大きい家具が入るか分かりません。

examples.en: This furniture shop has a variety of furniture, such as beds, sofas, tables, and more.
examples.ja: この家具屋さんにはベッド、ソファ、テーブルなど、色々なの家具があります。

examples.en: This is money for you to buy furniture. It's not money for going to a host club.
examples.ja: これは、あなたが家具を買うためのお金です。ホストクラブに行くためのお金ではありません。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>tools</kanji> aren't the tools you use to build a house. They're more like the things that are a part of your house that you use like tools. Those things would be your <vocabulary>furniture</vocabulary>. So, remember, your house tools are just furniture.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the か reading with 家事, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

The best kind of <vocabulary>furniture</vocabulary> is a <reading>car</reading> (か). If you think about it, anybody would be impressed to find a car inside your house. Is that a car, they'd ask. Oh, that's just a piece of furniture, you'd say, I use it as a bed. Car furniture is such a flex.

examples.en: I will receive a phone call from my teacher tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日、先生から電話を受ける。

examples.en: This time, I decided to take the JLPT exam in winter.
examples.ja: 今回はJLPTの試験を冬に受ける事にしました。

examples.en: You don't have to take what others say seriously every time.
examples.ja: 他人から言われた事を、毎回まともに受けなくてもいいんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>receive</kanji>, and this verb means just about the same thing: <vocabulary>to receive something</vocabulary>!

This is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. But 受ける often implies passive reception, generally of intangible objects like an education, or damage. It can also mean <vocabulary>to take something</vocabulary>, like taking an exam or a job offer.
reading_mnemonic: There’s a creature in front of you that’s about <vocabulary>to receive something</vocabulary>, but what is it? It’s an <reading>u</reading>ni (う), and it’s going to receive a warm welcome and an education. Picture the sea urchin receiving these things, and then going on to take an exam to prove how much education it’s received.

examples.en: I like Japanese sweets.
examples.ja: 私、和風スイーツがすきなんです。

examples.en: We are out of the Japanese-style sesame dressing, can you go buy it?
examples.ja: 和風ごまドレッシングが切れちゃったんだけど、買ってきてくれる？

examples.en: I’d like a Japanese-style room. Is there a vacancy?
examples.ja: 和風の客室がいいんですが、空室はありますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> <kanji>style</kanji>. The Japanese often like to think they're very unique and have a very special kind of style (and often times they do). So, you'll hear this word used when someone wants to describe this unique sense of style. Wafuuuu! 

Note that this word uses alternative kanji meanings in both of the kanji. They're in the kanji explanation, but they're not the primaries, so it may take a little extra effort to learn this word depending on what you studied!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to make it a peaceful town for the residents.
examples.ja: 住人にとって平和な町にしたいです。

examples.en: Many people say that Japan is too peaceful.
examples.ja: 「日本は平和すぎる」と言う人も、多いですよ。

examples.en: May the world be peaceful as soon as possible.
examples.ja: 一日でも早く世界が平和になりますように。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>flat</kanji> <kanji>peace</kanji>. This is a peace that will last, because there's no waves... no ripples... just flat. This is plain old <vocabulary>peace</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like having Japanese-style food for breakfast.
examples.ja: 朝ごはんは、和食がいいです。

examples.en: My Japanese husband cooks Japanese food every day.
examples.ja: 日本人の主人は毎日和食を作ってくれます。

examples.en: I ate wagyu steak at a Japanese restaurant.
examples.ja: 和食レストランで、和牛のステーキを食べました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> <kanji>eat</kanji> ... well, let's change "eat" to "food" and you have <vocabulary>Japanese style food</vocabulary>. This is a good way to differentiate between an American style restaurant and a Japanese style restaurant. What kind of food you feeling like tonight? Oh, how about some 和食?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to buy an antique sofa for this Japanese-style room.
examples.ja: この和室にアンティークのソファを買いたいと思っています。

examples.en: My sister's house has a Japanese-style room for drinking tea in it.
examples.ja: 姉の家には、お茶を飲むための和室があります。

examples.en: A room with a tatami floor is called a Japanese-style room.
examples.ja: タタミがある部屋のことを和室と言います。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> tends to be pretty small. This mainly refers to the kind of room that's covered in tatami mats, though. If you're looking for places to stay in Japan, a 和室 will be something like that. You'll pull the futon out of the closet and sleep on the floor. So comfy, these <vocabulary>Japanese style room</vocabulary>s!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Japanese style clothes like kimono are a part of Japanese culture.
examples.ja: キモノなどの和服は、日本の文化の一部です。

examples.en: My grandmother is good at making Japanese style clothing.
examples.ja: うちのおばあちゃんは和服を作るのが上手です。

examples.en: Have you seen Japanese people running marathons in Japanese style clothes?
examples.ja: 和服でマラソンをする日本人を見たことがありますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Japanese style</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> (<vocabulary>Japanese Style Clothes</vocabulary>). We're talking kimonos and yukata and things like that. Basically, this differentiates Japanese clothing from Western clothing. 

What kind of clothes will you wear to the festival tonight? Oh, probably some 和服.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What are your plans for tomorrow?
examples.ja: 明日の予定は何ですか？

examples.en: I plan to go eat shaved ice with friends this weekend.
examples.ja: 今週末は友人とかき氷を食べに行く予定です。

examples.en: I have to take a rest because of the flu, even though I already made plans for next week.
examples.ja: せっかく来週の予定を立てたのに、インフルエンザのせいで休まなければいけません。

meaning_mnemonic: Something has been <kanji>determine</kanji>d <kanji>beforehand</kanji>. What is this thing? This action? It is a <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I can't decide right away.
examples.ja: 今すぐは決定出来ません。

examples.en: We'll decide in tomorrow's meeting whether to open a branch in the United States.
examples.ja: アメリカに支店をオープンするかどうかは明日のミーティングで決定します。

examples.en: Horikoshi-sensei, how do you feel about the decision to animate your manga?
examples.ja: ホリコシ先生、ご自分のマンガのアニメ化決定について、どう思われますか？

meaning_mnemonic: It's been <kanji>decide</kanji>d and <kanji>determine</kanji>d. The <vocabulary>decision</vocabulary> has been made.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the shortened けつ in 決. It goes to けっ.

examples.en: This woman is not my true mother.
examples.ja: この女の人は、私の実の母ではありません。

examples.en: My profile says twenty-five years old, but in reality, I'm actually thirty-five years old.
examples.ja: プロフィールでは２５才と言ってるんですが、実は私３５才なんです。

examples.en: As a matter of fact, I've been on the Olympics even though I may not look like it.
examples.ja: 実を言うと私、こう見えてもオリンピックに出たことがあるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading, same like you learned with the kanji. That is the truth, I promise.

examples.en: All of the above is factual.
examples.ja: 以上は、全て事実です。

examples.en: This book has many facts about mathematics.
examples.ja: この本には、数学にまつわる事実がたくさんのってます。

examples.en: It's a fact that all Japanese people know, but crabs in Tottori are delicious.
examples.ja: 全日本の人々が知っている事実だが、鳥取のカニはおいしい。

examples.en: Dad, in fact, knew about that.
examples.ja: 父は事実、それを知っていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>occurrence</kanji> of <kanji>truth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fact</vocabulary>.

事実 is primarily used as a noun, but it can also be used to say something is <vocabulary>factual</vocabulary>. Additionally, in relatively formal writing it can be used as an adverb to mean <vocabulary>in fact</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Even if I used all of my true strength, it was still a draw.
examples.ja: 全ての実力を出しても、同点の引き分けでした。

examples.en: The younger brother seems to be worried about why he cannot be a professional, despite his true strength.
examples.ja: 弟は実力があるのに、なぜプロになれないのか不安に思っているようです。

examples.en: Koichi's hula dancing abilities are genuine.
examples.ja: コウイチのフラダンスの実力は本物です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>truth</kanji> behind someone's <kanji>strength</kanji> is their <vocabulary>true strength</vocabulary>. It is also their <vocabulary>true ability</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your <vocabulary>true strength</vocabulary> is sealed behind two locks. <reading>Gee, two</reading> <reading>lock</reading>s (じつりょく)?! People must have been scared of your <vocabulary>true power</vocabulary> to seal it behind two locks!

examples.en: Those clothes are cute.
examples.ja: その服、かわいいね。

examples.en: My mother's lucky color is red, so she always wears red clothes.
examples.ja: うちの母は、ラッキーカラーが赤なので、いつも赤い服をきています。

examples.en: Why is it that I never have enough clothes no matter how many I own?!
examples.ja: どれだけ持っていても服が足りないのは、なぜ？！

examples.en: Put all the clothes in the drawer.
examples.ja: 服を全部引き出しの中に入れてください。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji and uses the on'yomi even though it's a single word. Very strange, but convenient for you so long as you remember this exception reading word.

examples.en: Swimming in the sea is not safe because the typhoon is approaching.
examples.ja: 台風が近づいてるので、海で泳ぐのは安全ではありません。

examples.en: I want to swim like a mermaid someday.
examples.ja: いつか人魚みたいに泳ぎたいんだ。

examples.en: Even though it's a municipal pool, it still costs money to swim.
examples.ja: 市立プールだからといって、泳ぐにはお金がかかります。

examples.en: Hey, your eyes are shifty.
examples.ja: あんた、目が泳いでるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>swim</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to swim</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana sticking out?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: There are too many things in this house.
examples.ja: この家には物がありすぎます。

examples.en: We don't have food for tomorrow, so I'm going to the supermarket.
examples.ja: 明日食べる物がないので、スーパーに買いに行ってきます。

examples.en: The other day, I found something I lost a year ago.
examples.ja: 先日、一年前に失くした物を見つけたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Besides <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>, it has the related meanings of <vocabulary>object</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>item</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

What game has the most <vocabulary>thing</vocabulary>s in it? <reading>Mono</reading>poly (もの). You can choose from a bunch of random things to play as, you know? And no one actually knows what those things are. What's a thimble anyway? Just call it a thing.

examples.en: What are Kyushu's local specialties?
examples.ja: 九州の名物は何ですか？

examples.en: Koichi is the famous president of Tofugu.
examples.ja: コウイチは、トーフグの名物社長です。

examples.en: Portland's specialties are hipsters, old carpets, and delicious coffee.
examples.ja: ポートランドの名物は、ヒップスターと、古いカーペットと、おいしいコーヒーです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>famous</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> of an area is their <vocabulary>famous product</vocabulary>, but it sounds better in English if you say it's the <vocabulary>local specialty</vocabulary>. When you're traveling around Japan, be sure to be on the lookout for the 名物! It's always fun.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I ate so much that I'm in pain.
examples.ja: 食べすぎて苦しい。

examples.en: These jeans have been uncomfortably tight since about a month ago.
examples.ja: 一ヶ月前くらいから、このジーンズ、苦しいんだ。

examples.en: Remembering what happened back then still makes my heart ache.
examples.ja: あの時のことを思い出すと、今でも心が苦しい。

examples.en: In the village, there was not enough food in winter, and all the villagers lived in hardship.
examples.ja: 村では、冬になると食べ物が不足して、村人はみんな苦しい生活を送っていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word ends in い, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. In fact, it ends in しい, which makes it even more likely it's an adjective. Since the kanji 苦 means <kanji>suffering</kanji>, this word is the adjective version of that: <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary>.

苦しい usually describes a painful or <vocabulary>distressing</vocabulary> feeling that's ongoing and hard to endure, rather than a physical sensation of pain. For example, you can use 苦しい when it's hard to breathe, when you feel emotional pain, or even when your finances are <vocabulary>strained</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everything is really <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> right now. Why? You have something heavy on top of you, <reading>cru</reading>shing (くる) you.

examples.en: There are days when I get on the bus to go to the office.
examples.ja: 会社へ行くのに、バスに乗る日もあります。

examples.en: I couldn't get on a flight going to Tokyo.
examples.ja: 東京行きのフライトには乗れませんでした。

examples.en: The dog on that surfboard is cute!
examples.ja: あのサーフボードに乗ってる犬、かわいいね！

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ride</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to ride</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Enjoy the ride!

examples.en: When a customer comes in, you'll hear the sound of this bell.
examples.ja: お客さんが入ってくると、このベルの音がします。

examples.en: I served tea to the customer.
examples.ja: お客さんにお茶を出しました。

examples.en: You are one of our precious WaniKani customers.
examples.ja: あなたは大切なワニカニのお客さんの一人なんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The さん on the end is the name honorific さん. It's there to show some respect. It's like saying "Mr. Guest!" or something like that. But that sounds dumb in English. We'll just call this word <vocabulary>guest</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>visitor</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>customer</vocabulary>. You'll hear this word a lot when you're at a store or you're a customer somewhere in Japan. You are the お客さん, in that situation. Alternatively, you'll also hear お客さま which is a more polite version of this word (because it ends in さま and not さん).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.

examples.en: The guest room was large and had two beds.
examples.ja: 客室は広く、ベッドが二つありました。

examples.en: Sure enough, rooms with ocean views are expensive.
examples.ja: 海が見える客室は、やはり高いです。

examples.en: At this hotel, all the rooms have concierge service.
examples.ja: このホテルでは全ての客室にコンシェルジュサービスが付いてきます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>guest</kanji>'s <kanji>room</kanji> is the <vocabulary>guest room</vocabulary> (the room you put guests in, duh!).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I was little, I wanted to work in a cake shop when I became an adult.
examples.ja: 小さい時は、大人になったらケーキ屋さんになりたいと思ってました。

examples.en: There is a famous tonkotsu ramen shop in this town.
examples.ja: この町には有名なとんこつラーメン屋があります。

examples.en: The other day, a man I met at the bakery asked me for my phone number.
examples.ja: この前、パン屋で会った男の人に電話番号をきかれたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You'll see this attached to other words... like "meat" or "fish." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ store, making this word mean <vocabulary>store</vocabulary> (same as the kanji).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.

examples.en: There's a bed in my room.
examples.ja: 私の部屋にはベッドがあります。

examples.en: The room is facing south, so it gets good sunlight.
examples.ja: 南を向いた部屋なので、日当たりがすごくいいんです。

examples.en: I plan to clean the room this afternoon.
examples.ja: 今日の午後は部屋のクリーニングをする予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>part</kanji> of a <kanji>roof</kanji>, that part is your <vocabulary>room</vocabulary>. Just imagine a roof divided into sections in a house, with the sections going all the way down to the ground. Each section is its own room, right?
reading_mnemonic:
部屋 is a bit tricky because it's one of the few Japanese words that use the へ reading for 部. You'll just have to remember this one is special. Here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Imagine you're renting out a <vocabulary>room</vocabulary>, but all you hear at night is a constant "<reading>heh</reading> (へ)… heh... heh... hehehe". An incessant snickering, coming from somewhere inside your room. Hehehe.

examples.en: I bought 400 grams of beef at the butcher shop.
examples.ja: 肉屋さんで牛肉を四百グラム買いました。

examples.en: Japanese butchers sell croquettes and cutlets.
examples.ja: 日本の肉屋さんでは、コロッケやカツなどが売ってますよ。

examples.en: In the small town where I was born, there was a vegetarian restaurant named "Butcher." Now that I recall it, it's kind of a sarcastic name.
examples.ja: 私の生まれた小さい町には「お肉屋さん」と言う名前のベジタリアンのレストランがあったの。今思い出すと、なんだか皮肉な名前よね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>meat</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a place that sells meat. Who sells meat? A <vocabulary>butcher shop</vocabulary>!

肉屋 often refers to the butcher shop, but it can also mean the actual butchers who work there. You might also see this as お肉屋さん, but that won't change the meaning — it can still be either the shop or the butcher, depending on context!
reading_mnemonic: For 肉 you use the にく reading (which you learned with the kanji). For 屋 you use the kun'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Basically, if you learned the kanji readings, you can read this word!

examples.en: This town has an old tea house.
examples.ja: この町には古い茶屋があります。

examples.en: Would you like to go into the teahouse and take a little break?
examples.ja: 茶屋に入って少し休みませんか？

examples.en: There is a bamboo grove in front of the teahouse, and there is also a red Japanese umbrella.
examples.ja: 茶屋の前には竹林があって、赤い和風のパラソルもあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>tea</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a <vocabulary>tea shop</vocabulary>. Mmm, delicious, delicious tea.

Traditionally, a 茶屋 was a Japanese <vocabulary>teahouse</vocabulary> where travelers could rest and enjoy tea and snacks. These kinds of 茶屋 are less common today, but the term is still often used for cafes or restaurants designed to evoke the charm of historical Japanese teahouses.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We bought some raw salmon at a fish shop.
examples.ja: 魚屋さんで生のサーモンを買いました。

examples.en: The fish shop will cut the fish you buy.
examples.ja: 魚屋さんは買った魚を切ってくれますよ。

examples.en: The owner of that fish shop runs the shop during the day, but at night he's the drummer in a rock band.
examples.ja: あそこの魚屋さんのご主人、日中は魚屋さんだけど、夜はロックバンドのドラマーなんですって。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fish</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fish shop</vocabulary>, a place from which you buy fish. Especially in Japan, very important.
reading_mnemonic: The kun'yomi reading is used for the 魚 (so it's さかな) and the kun'yomi reading is used for 屋 (や). You'll have to use the reading of 魚 from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.

examples.en: My friend is a designer in Nagoya.
examples.ja: 私の友人は名古屋でデザイナーをしています。

examples.en: The breakfast culture in Nagoya is famous all over the country.
examples.ja: 名古屋の朝ごはん文化は全国で有名です。

examples.en: Which is the highest building in Nagoya City?
examples.ja: 名古屋市内で一番高いビルはどれですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The place that's <kanji>famous</kanji> for <kanji>old</kanji> <kanji>roof</kanji>s. I don't know why, but it's the city of <vocabulary>Nagoya</vocabulary>. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji (except for 名 and 屋, which are kun'yomi here). If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For な just think to 名前 (なまえ) which uses the な reading. The "name" (名前) of this city is what? It's <reading>Na</reading>goya. Watch out for rendaku changing こ to ご too.

examples.en: Okay, then let’s do it next time.
examples.ja: じゃあ、やっぱり今度にしよう。

examples.en: I'm planning to go see the cherry blossoms with my friends this time.
examples.ja: 今度、友人と花見に行く予定です。

examples.en: This summer vacation I'm going to Shikoku.
examples.ja: 今度の夏休みは四国に行くつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic: In the <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> you'll learn your kanji, no? This word means <vocabulary>this time</vocabulary>. Despite being "this time" it has the feeling of <vocabulary>next time</vocabulary>, though. It's like saying "okay, this time we'll get it" where "this time" really means "next time," making it a little bit different from 今回.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I just got out of the bath.
examples.ja: 丁度、おふろから出たところです。

examples.en: The size of these clothes is just right.
examples.ja: この服の大きさが丁度いいです。

examples.en: I was just looking for that book.
examples.ja: 丁度その本を探していたんです。

examples.en: Oh! I was planning to call you just now!
examples.ja: あら！今丁度あなたに電話をしようと思っていたところよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Okay, we're going to cheat a little bit to remember the meaning of this word. Let's say you take the temperature of the <kanji>street</kanji>. It is exactly one hundred <kanji>degree</kanji>s. That's <vocabulary>exactly</vocabulary> what it is. <vocabulary>Just</vocabulary> 100 degrees, not one degree more or less. You put your eggs on the street and watch them cook.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Every time, I get the same error.
examples.ja: 毎度、同じエラーが出るんですよ。

examples.en: Of course, I always ignore hateful replies.
examples.ja: もちろんクソリプは毎度スルーだよ。

examples.en: This always happens, but it’s taking a long time for Kyoko to decide on what to wear today too.
examples.ja: 毎度のことだが、キョーコは今日も服を決めるのに時間がかかっている。

meaning_mnemonic: When something happens at <kanji>every</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> and at <kanji>every</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>, it's something that happens <vocabulary>frequently</vocabulary>. It happens <vocabulary>each time</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It took a while to get the angle right.
examples.ja: 正しい角度にするのに時間がかかりました。

examples.en: I would like to think about this from various angles.
examples.ja: これについては、色々な角度から見て考えてみたいと思います。

examples.en: Each angle is sixty degrees, which means it's an "equilateral triangle."
examples.ja: 一つの角度が全て六十度ということは、それは「正三角形」ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>angle</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>angle</vocabulary>. 90 degrees? 160 degrees? They're all still angles when you come down to it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In Tokyo in summer, there are many days where it gets above thirty degrees.
examples.ja: 東京の夏は、三十度以上になる日が多いです。

examples.en: First, heat the oven to 190 degrees.
examples.ja: 先ず、オーブンを１９０度にして下さい。

examples.en: The angle here is ninety degrees.
examples.ja: ここの角度は、９０度です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji <kanji>degree</kanji> can mean both degree in terms of angles and degree in terms of temperature. This word is how you talk about these things. Just attach it to a number and you have yourself the number of <vocabulary>degrees</vocabulary> that something is. After the numbers 1, 2 and 3 (and in some other situations) this can also mean <vocabulary>times</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned. When writing out the answer to this reading, omit the 〜 as it's only there to let you know that some other word should come before it.

examples.en: I decided to have my own car before I turned thirty.
examples.ja: 三十才になるまでに自分の車を持つと決めたんです。

examples.en: What is that man holding in his left hand?
examples.ja: あの男、左手に何を持ってるんですか？

examples.en: When you go out in the summer, be sure to carry water and a towel.
examples.ja: 夏に出かけるときは、水とタオルを必ず持っていきましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>hold</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to carry something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to own something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to keep something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You hold something, like chopsticks, have something, like power, or keep something, like your friend's book over the weekend.
reading_mnemonic: If you try <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary> in your hand long enough it will <reading>mo</reading>ld (も). And then that mold will cover your hand, then your arm, then your entire body. Basically, you should never hold anything for too long or you'll become a mold person.

examples.en: The world is big, so I want to go to various countries.
examples.ja: 世界は広いから、色々な国に行きたいです。

examples.en: This documentary has become a popular masterpiece worldwide.
examples.ja: このドキュメンタリーは全世界で人気の大作になりました。

examples.en: Many artists have a world of their own.
examples.ja: アーティストは、自分の世界を持ってる人が多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: Both kanji mean <kanji>world</kanji>, so it should be easy to guess this is a word for <vocabulary>the World</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>society</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the Universe</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the on'yomi reading for 界, but you didn't learn this on'yomi reading of 世, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

What's the most hated vegetable in <vocabulary>the world</vocabulary>? <reading>Ce</reading>lery (せ), probably. The world is divided into those who love celery and those who hate celery. Which one are you?

examples.en: "Handmade Cheesecake" is on sale starting today!
examples.ja: 今日から「手作りチーズケーキ」の発売です！

examples.en: This is an announcement to all our fans. Our merchandise will be released online first.
examples.ja: ファンのみんなにお知らせです。私たちのグッズが先ずはオンラインで発売されることになりました。

examples.en: My sister has been in front of the store since twelve hours before the release of the new smartphone.
examples.ja: 私の姉は、新しいスマートフォン発売の十二時間前から、お店の前にいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You want things to <kanji>depart</kanji> from your store so you have to <kanji>sell</kanji> them. You put all these things up for <vocabulary>sale</vocabulary>. You are <vocabulary>selling</vocabulary> these items.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you tell me the pronunciation of "Otolaryngology"?
examples.ja: 「Otolaryngology」の発音を教えてくれませんか？

examples.en: After the teacher corrected my pronunciation of L and R, I became able to pronounce them well.
examples.ja: 先生がLとRの発音を正してくれてからは、上手に発音出来るようになりました。

examples.en: I am training in pronunciation to improve my speaking skills.
examples.ja: スピーキング力を上げるため、発音のトレーニングをしています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sound</kanji> that <kanji>departs</kanji> from your mouth is you talking. Imagine yourself saying things and words departing your mouth. They are bent in different ways and have different colors, highlighting your <vocabulary>pronunciation</vocabulary> of certain words and phrases.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I found a caterpillar on a tree.
examples.ja: 木の上に毛虫を発見しました。

examples.en: If you live in a foreign country, you'll make discoveries every day.
examples.ja: 外国で生活をしていると、毎日発見があります。

examples.en: With this old map, you may be able to find some treasure.
examples.ja: この古い地図があれば、宝を発見することが出来るかもしれない。

meaning_mnemonic: You make <kanji>departure</kanji> from your home off into the great beyond. You will go to <kanji>see</kanji> the unseen, and hopefully make a great <vocabulary>discovery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the はつ part, which gets shortened to はっ. The 見 is unlike what you learned with 見, though. 

In order to remember that this is けん, imagine you're going out to make a discovery of some strange new lands. With strange new lands, there comes strange new people. This one has a samurai named <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) on it. He's trying to discover new things too!

examples.en: Hey, I have something I want to discuss with you.
examples.ja: ねえ、相談があるんだけど。

examples.en: Home loan consultation is from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.
examples.ja: 家のローン相談は、午後六時から午後九時です。

examples.en: When I consulted the doctor, I was told, "First, try to live a life without stress."
examples.ja: 医者に相談したら「先ずはストレスのない生活をして下さい」と言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>. Both sides are talking to each other and the feelings are mutual. Imagine you're discussing a problem. You want to get help with it, so you get some <vocabulary>consultation</vocabulary> from your friend. This <vocabulary>discussion</vocabulary> was very helpful.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What prefecture are you from?
examples.ja: 何県の出身ですか。

examples.en: I have been to Ishikawa prefecture three times.
examples.ja: 石川県には三回行ったことがありますよ。

examples.en: Yamaguchi prefecture's specialty is puffer fish.
examples.ja: 山口県の名物はフグです。

meaning_mnemonic: Attach this word onto the end of a prefecture place name and you have the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> portion of _____ <vocabulary>prefecture</vocabulary>. These are a lot like states or provinces.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's always attached to things (so it's like jukugo). Don't write the 〜 when you're writing in the answer, just the けん portion, and you'll get this one correct.

examples.en: This blue flower is very beautiful.
examples.ja: この青い花、とても美しいですね。

examples.en: The river called "Shimanto River" in Shikoku is one of Japan's beautiful rivers.
examples.ja: 四国の「四万十川」という名の川は日本の美しい川の一つです。

examples.en: The eyes of this doll are beautiful like jewels.
examples.ja: この人形の目は、宝石のように美しいですね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. More precisely, it has しい on the end, which makes it even more likely it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>beauty</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you. It's a long reading for a mnemonic, but try your best. 

You look at someone who is <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>. What an easy life they've lived. No hard work and all they do is pamper themselves to stay beautiful. Feel disgusted. You walk up to this person and say: "<reading>U too cushy</reading>! (うつくしい). 

Sorry for adding the whole word in there for the reading mnemonic, but I thought it worked out better that way. Just know that the word isn't うつくしいしい or something weird like that. The hiragana on the end is part of the mnemonic as well.

examples.en: That woman is a very elegant beauty.
examples.ja: あの女の人は、とてもエレガントな美人ですね。

examples.en: When I asked for her phone number, I just couldn't say, "You're a beautiful woman."
examples.ja: 電話番号をきく時、「あなた美人ですね」ってどうしても言えなかったんだよ。

examples.en: He said, "I don't need anyone's advice," but then he said he would welcome advice from beautiful women.
examples.ja: あいつ、「だれの助言もいらない」って言ってたのに、美人の助言はウェルカムなんだとよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>beautiful</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>beautiful woman</vocabulary>. Wait, why isn't this a beautiful person? In fact, this word used to have a broader meaning, but for some reason it's generally only used for women in modern Japanese.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Where you're from, every <vocabulary>beautiful woman</vocabulary> wears <reading>bee</reading> <reading>jean</reading>s (びじん). That's right, jeans made out of bees. Beauty knows no pain after all!

examples.en: My brother is always worried about losing.
examples.ja: 兄は、いつも負けることを不安に思っています。

examples.en: Even if you lose with your body, don't lose with your heart.
examples.ja: 体は負けても、心は負けないで。

examples.en: "What should we eat?" "It's your call. I lost in rock-paper-scissors."
examples.ja: 「何食べようか？」「あなたが決めてよ。私はじゃんけんに負けたんだから。」

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lose</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to lose</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You lose your tournament/soccer game/whatever (you decide something applicable to you). You're sad about this. Who's there to comfort you? Your <reading>Ma</reading> (ま). She's a nice lady.

examples.en: The match was a draw.
examples.ja: 勝負は引き分けだった。

examples.en: I think this year is the year of challenges.
examples.ja: 今年は、私にとって勝負の年だと思っています。

examples.en: You only have one shot at this, so please give it your all.
examples.ja: これは一発勝負なので、全力を出して下さいね。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Win</kanji>, <kanji>lose</kanji>... both will happen in tonight's <vocabulary>match</vocabulary>! What a <vocabulary>showdown</vocabulary> it will be!

Note that 勝負 can also describe situations where one takes a significant risk or makes a bold move— <vocabulary>a gamble </vocabulary>—with high stakes involved.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ふ becomes ぶ because of rendaku here.

examples.en: Tom always wins with skill.
examples.ja: トムはいつも実力で勝つ。

examples.en: I did a lot of training in order to win.
examples.ja: 勝つために、たくさんトレーニングをしました。

examples.en: Maria is always working hard to win.
examples.ja: マリアはいつも勝つためにがんばっている。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>win</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to win</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What did you just <vocabulary>win</vocabulary>? You won a new <reading>ca</reading>r (か)!

examples.en: The winners of this race will get some money.
examples.ja: このレースの勝者はお金がもらえますよ。

examples.en: Only the winner can proceed to the next stage.
examples.ja: 勝者だけが次のステージにすすめます。

examples.en: The idea that going to a famous university will make you a winner in life is an old way of thinking.
examples.ja: 有名な大学に行ったら人生の勝者になれるだなんて考え方、古いですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who <kanji>win</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>winner</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>victor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The book about successful marriage proposals is likely to be a bestseller this year.
examples.ja: プロポーズ必勝の本が今年のベストセラーになりそうです。

examples.en: Thinking she would definitely win, my sister spent 20,000 yen on the lottery.
examples.ja: 姉は必勝すると思い、宝くじに二万円を使った。

examples.en: Can I really win if I use this "Pachinko Surefire Win Manual"?
examples.ja: この『パチンコ必勝マニュアル』を使えば本当に勝てるのでしょうか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>win</kanji> sounds like a great thing. When these two kanji are put together, a <vocabulary>certain victory</vocabulary> is inevitable.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the つ in ひつ is turned into a small っ, though.

examples.en: This test was a piece of cake.
examples.ja: 今回のテストは、楽勝だったね。

examples.en: ”How was the JLPT5?" "Thanks to WaniKani, it was easy peasy."
examples.ja: 「JLPT5はどうだった？」「ワニカニのおかげで、楽勝だったよ。」

examples.en: That game is such a piece of cake that it's just kinda boring.
examples.ja: あのゲームは楽勝すぎて、なんかつまらないんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>win</kanji> that was an <kanji>ease</kanji>. That is an <vocabulary>easy victory</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>easy win</vocabulary>. Don't hope for a lot of these, though. Hope for tough wins instead, they actually make you better.

Note that this can be used both literally, to describe an easy victory at a game or contest; or more figuratively, to describe something as “easy” in general.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: At the end of every year, I send a handmade postcard to my friends.
examples.ja: 毎年、年末には友人に手作りのポストカードを送る。

examples.en: I'll send you the video from earlier via LINE.
examples.ja: さっきのビデオ、LINEで送るね。

examples.en: Let’s call it a day. I’ll walk you home.
examples.ja: 今日は、ここまでにしよう。家まで送るよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>send</kanji>, and the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to send something</vocabulary>. If the object of this verb is a person, it means "to send" in the sense of <vocabulary>to escort someone</vocabulary>, maybe to the station, or to the door.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You need to send an entire <reading>oak</reading> (おく) tree in the mail, but it's too big. Imagine yourself dragging one to the post office. They tell you that you can't send that here... Go to the oak sending facilities.

examples.en: The important thing is to be healthy.
examples.ja: 重要なのは、元気でいることです。

examples.en: When I was in elementary school, I thought it was important to make friends at school.
examples.ja: 小学生の時、私は学校で友達を作ることが重要だと思っていました。

examples.en: It was an important announcement for the people.
examples.ja: それは、国民にとって重要なお知らせでした。

meaning_mnemonic: When something has a <kanji>heavy</kanji> <kanji>need</kanji>, you know that that thing is <vocabulary>essential</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>important</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is Anna’s body weight in kilograms?
examples.ja: アンナさんの体重は、何キロですか？

examples.en: Our dog ​​got fat last year, but she lost the weight all at once on a desperate diet.
examples.ja: うちの犬は去年太ったが、必死のダイエットで一気に体重が下がりました。

examples.en: Excuse me. This weight takes my contact lenses into account too, right?
examples.ja: すみません。この体重、コンタクトレンズの分も入ってますよね？

meaning_mnemonic: How <kanji>heavy</kanji> is your <kanji>body</kanji>? Figure that out and you'll have your <vocabulary>body weight</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please draw a double line under characters you're not sure about.
examples.ja: 分からない文字の下に、二重のラインを引いて下さい。

examples.en: This fish has a strong smell, so I'll double wrap it.
examples.ja: この魚はニオイが強いので、ラップを二重にしておきますね。

examples.en: This is an exercise to get rid of double chins.
examples.ja: これは、二重アゴをなくすためのエクササイズです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>heavy</kanji> things, you have <vocabulary>double</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dual</vocabulary> the heavy (compared to one, at least). 

This word is a prefix attached to other words to show that it is "double." 二重 kanji time!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm going to a supermarket. Do you need anything?
examples.ja: スーパーに行くけど、何か必要なものはありますか？

examples.en: You need to walk a little after getting off the bus.
examples.ja: バスをおりてから、少し歩く必要があります。

examples.en: Do you really need everything in that mountain of the clothes?
examples.ja: その服の山、本当に全部必要なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>certain</kanji> that you <kanji>need</kanji> it. This thing is <vocabulary>necessary</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>needed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please say the main points first.
examples.ja: 要点だけ先に言ってください。

examples.en: Get to the point! I don't care about small details.
examples.ja: 早く要点を言ってよ！小さいことはどうでもいいの。

examples.en: If the point of the sentence is not clear, ask AI for help.
examples.ja: 文の要点が明らかでない時は、AIに助けてもらいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>need</kanji>ed <kanji>point</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main point</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> of what you're trying to say.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Supposing it rains tomorrow, the picnic will be canceled.
examples.ja: 仮に明日雨だったら、ピクニックは中止になる。

examples.en: Hypothetically, if I can't enter university, I think joining my father's company is also an option.
examples.ja: 仮に大学に入学できなかったら、父の会社に入社するのも一つの手だと思っています。

examples.en: If this bed was made of grass, it might have been eaten by cows.
examples.ja: 仮に、このベッドが草で出来ていたとしたら、牛たちに食べられてしまったかもしれないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji itself means <kanji>temporary</kanji>. When you add the に, we're asking you to imagine a situation temporarily, so the meaning changes to <vocabulary>supposing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>if</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it: 

<vocabulary>If</vocabulary> you don't mind, could you <reading>carry</reading> (かり) this for me? <vocabulary>Supposing</vocabulary> it's not too much trouble, of course.

examples.en: Have you learned all the kana?
examples.ja: もう全ての仮名を学びましたか？

examples.en: Sentences written only in kana are difficult to understand.
examples.ja: 仮名だけで書かれた文は、分かりにくいです。

examples.en: Does this book have kana?
examples.ja: この本には、ふり仮名がついてますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>name</kanji>s. These are the <vocabulary>kana</vocabulary> (that's hiragana and katakana). Why are kana the "temporary names" though? Maybe they were just meant to be a temporary way to write the names of the kanji you didn't know how to write yet. That's just a guess, but it should help you remember that this word means "kana."
reading_mnemonic:
Okay, so 仮 uses the rare kun'yomi reading か, which you haven't learned yet, but luckily it's the same as the on'yomi you have learned! And 名 also uses a kun'yomi reading that you learned with the vocab word 名 (な). So you sort of know these readings already, but it's a lot to take in, so here's a mnemonic to help: 

The reading is so tricky for <vocabulary>kana</vocabulary> that it makes you say <reading>かな</reading>… (I wonder…) whenever you try to read it. You keep thinking, "Is the reading kana, かな? Or could it be something else, かな?" You're just not sure.

examples.en: It is not a assumption, but the truth.
examples.ja: それは、仮定ではなく、本当のことです。

examples.en: For example, if we say one dollar is one hundred yen, then one can of $1 coca cola is one hundred yen, right?
examples.ja: たとえば、一ドル百円と仮定すると、一本一ドルのコカコーラは百円になりますよね？

examples.en: Before making a hypothesis, really think again about your reasons for making it.
examples.ja: 仮定を立てる前に、もう一回しっかりと仮定を立てる理由を考えましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>determination</kanji> is something you're not totally sure about. You've decided to think of something in a certain way, but only for now. If more information comes to light, you may change your mind. That's why this word means <vocabulary>assumption</vocabulary>.

仮定 refers to making tentative assumptions about a specific situation to discuss what might happen under certain conditions, such as "if we <vocabulary>assume</vocabulary> I dropped my wallet here yesterday...”
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Turn right on this road and you'll find a convenience store.
examples.ja: この道を右に曲がると、コンビニがあります。

examples.en: I feel like my ankle is bent.
examples.ja: 足首が曲がっている気がするんです。

examples.en: Your mustard-colored necktie is a bit crooked.
examples.ja: そのマスタード色のネクタイ、ちょっと曲がってるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means both music and bend. For this word, we're looking at "bend." So the verb 曲がる is to be bent. It's intransitive, so don't give it a direct object. Use it to say something gets bent or bends: a knee is bent, the road bends — that sort of thing. Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 曲げる, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: Peru is one of the countries in South America.
examples.ja: ペルーは南米の国の一つです。

examples.en: When I was a student, I went to South America as a backpacker.
examples.ja: 学生時代に、バックパッカーとして南米に行きました。

examples.en: South America is by no means a part of the United States!
examples.ja: 南米は決して米国の一部ではありませんよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 米国 means "America" (the country)? The 米 kanji can actually be used for either of the American continents. In this word we have <kanji>south</kanji> combining with <kanji>America</kanji>, so it must mean… <vocabulary>South America</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't seen the 南 reading (なん), so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

In <vocabulary>South America</vocabulary> everyone eats <reading>naan</reading> (なん). You may be surprised, since naan isn't exactly considered South American food. But what is a flour tortilla, really? It's South American naan!

examples.en: I'm not good at mingling with various people at parties.
examples.ja: パーティで色々な人と交わるのが下手なんです。

examples.en: The two roads intersect and become one road here.
examples.ja: 二つの道が交わって、ここで一つの道になります。

examples.en: Tofugu is a company where American and Japanese culture mingle.
examples.ja: トーフグは、アメリカと日本の文化が交わった会社です。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that the kanji means <kanji>mix</kanji> and the word 交ぜる means "to mix," so it probably has something to do with that. This word means <vocabulary>to intersect</vocabulary>, which is kind of like mixing. When two things intersect with each other, they're getting mixed up, so that's where this word gets its meaning. 

To remember that this one means "to intersect," remember the わ as <reading>wa</reading>lk. You're walking around, and then you intersect with some people on the street.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is almost the same as 交ぜる which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ま but it also has an extra じ in there. That じ is there because you intersect with a group of <reading>mage</reading>s (まじ) that catch you on fire as you walk past.

examples.en: I am an elementary school teacher.
examples.ja: 私は小学校の先生です。

examples.en: There are many foreign-born students in the elementary school in this town.
examples.ja: この町の小学校には、外国生まれの生徒もたくさんいますよ。

examples.en: I am in a volunteer club that reads picture books to elementary school children.
examples.ja: 小学校の子どもたちに、絵本をよむボランティアの会に入ってます。

examples.en: I've been interested in you since we were in elementary school.
examples.ja: 小学校の時から、君のこと、ずっと気になっていたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 学校 from a couple levels ago. Now we're adding a <kanji>small</kanji> to it. What is a "small school"? That's a school for small people, making it an <vocabulary>elementary school</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the regular on'yomi reading of 小 plus the vocab word 学校 that you've seen previously. Combine these two things for the reading of 小学校.

examples.en: Go to the right on this street.
examples.ja: この通りを右に行って下さい。

examples.en: Streets in the Shitamachi area have lots of shops, and people come and go throughout the day.
examples.ja: 下町の通りには、たくさんのお店が有って、一日中、人々が行ったり来たりします。

examples.en: There is a street called "Takeshita Street" in Tokyo, which is popular with junior high and high school students.
examples.ja: 東京には、「竹下通り」という名の通りがあって、中学生や高校生に人気です。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the word 通る hopefully by now. That is the verb version of this word, which means "to pass through." So, if this is the noun version, what is it that you use to pass through something? To drive or walk along? That would be an <vocabulary>avenue</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>street</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>road</vocabulary>, etc). This is a pretty common word in Japan, and good for not getting lost.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 通る, so as long as you know that, you should be able to read this one as well. Mind the strange long お sound!

examples.en: Please be careful of the fire on the stove.
examples.ja: ストーブの火に気を付けて下さい。

examples.en: It might rain today, so be careful and take a raincoat when you go out.
examples.ja: 今日は雨かもしれないから、外出する時は気を付けてレインコートをもってね。

examples.en: Be careful in big cities in this country, because there are many pickpockets.
examples.ja: この国の大きな町では、スリが多いから気をつけてね。

examples.en: It's not so bright around here, so watch your feet.
examples.ja: 辺りは明るくないので、足元に気をつけて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word contains the words 気 (energy) and 付ける (to attach). So, when you <kanji>attach</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> to something you're focusing in on it, right? This word is a sort of "order" as well, since it's te-form there at the end. It's a set phrase people say to other people who are doing dangerous things. It's kind of like saying "Attach energy to what you're doing! Stay focused!" A simpler way to translate this would be to say this word means <vocabulary>be careful</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>take care</vocabulary>, though. Learn this word so that you can always show that you're caring for your friends!
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the two words 気 and 付ける. So long as you know those from the previous levels, you should be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: This book is new.
examples.ja: この本は新しいです。

examples.en: The new apartment is clean, spacious, and close to the company.
examples.ja: 新しいアパートはきれいだし、広いし、会社からも近いんですよ。

examples.en: I'm sorry, this white shirt is still new, so could we get white wine instead of red wine today?
examples.ja: ごめんなさい。この白いシャツまだ新しいので、今日は赤ワインじゃなくて白ワインでもいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>new</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>new</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your family buys you a <vocabulary>new</vocabulary> Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an <reading>Atara</reading>... a knockoff video game system :(

examples.en: My little brother is a high school student.
examples.ja: 私の弟は高校生です。

examples.en: When I was in high school, I was in the tennis club.
examples.ja: 高校生の時は、テニス部に入ってました。

examples.en: Today, high school students are coming to tour this bread factory. Let's show them what a bread factory can do!
examples.ja: 今日は、高校生たちが、このパン工場の見学に来ます。パン工場の本気を見せましょう！

meaning_mnemonic: You know 高校 means "high school." So, a "life" that does high school is a <vocabulary>high school student</vocabulary>. This is like how 中学生 are middle school students and 小学生 are elementary school students!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Use the reading of 高校 from before to learn the reading of this word as well, if it helps.

examples.en: Junior high school students often come to this convenience store.
examples.ja: このコンビニには中学校の生徒がよく来ます。

examples.en: There is also a tea ceremony club in junior high school.
examples.ja: 中学校には茶道のクラブもありますよ。

examples.en: Thanks to my junior high school teacher, I started karate.
examples.ja: 中学校の時の先生のおかげで、空手をはじめたんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 学校 means school. So, people who are in the <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> are in... wait for it... <vocabulary>middle school</vocabulary>. 

And, of course, if you're one of those people that call it <vocabulary>junior high school</vocabulary> you can do that too.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of 学校 and 中. Really, it's all on'yomi too, so you should be able to read this one. Take note of the がく turning to がっ, though.

examples.en: There's no stamp attached to this letter yet.
examples.ja: この手紙には、まだ切手が付いてないですよ。

examples.en: Ugh, some ketchup got on my white tee shirt.
examples.ja: あーあ。白いティシャツにケチャップが付いちゃった。

examples.en: What’s that thing attached to your earlobe?
examples.ja: あなたの耳たぶに付いてるそれ、何？

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the word 付ける means "to attach" and you know that the kanji 付 means <kanji>attach</kanji>. So, this word probably has something to do with attaching. This is the intransitive version, though, where something is attached (and you're not doing the attaching). You can use the く as a hint. You see something attached on the wall. You say "Coo'"
reading_mnemonic: The reading can be derived from 付ける, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).

examples.en: Can you find my mother?
examples.ja: 私の母を見付けることが出来ますか？

examples.en: The other day, I found a gem under that tree.
examples.ja: 先日、あの木の下で宝石を見付けたんです。

examples.en: I was glad I could find a book I like today.
examples.ja: 今日は、自分の気に入った本を見付けることが出来たので、よかったです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 付ける means "to attach" and that 見 means "see." So, when you attach your seeing to something, it's like you're looking around trying <vocabulary>to find</vocabulary> something. When you find what you're looking for, imagine your eyeballs flying out and attaching to that item, then yelling "I FOUND IT!"

You'll usually see this word with the 付 in kana, so 見つける.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 見る and 付ける. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.

examples.en: People say my younger brother is a wimp.
examples.ja: 弟は弱虫だと言われている。

examples.en: My type is a man with a strong will but is a bit wimpy.
examples.ja: 気は強いけど、ちょっと弱虫な男がタイプです。

examples.en: No matter what you are — whether you're a wimp, or even a caterpillar, you should be just the way you are.
examples.ja: 弱虫だって毛虫だってなんだって、君は君のままでいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>weak</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji>. This is what people call <vocabulary>weakling</vocabulary>s in Japan. This is a good word to know if you're a bully, or something.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word 弱い from earlier and apply it here. 虫 should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji.

Just remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.

examples.en: My husband ran with all his might, despite his weak-looking body.
examples.ja: 主人は弱々しい体ながら全力で走った。

examples.en: The vehicle made a frail engine sound.
examples.ja: その車両は弱々しいエンジン音を立てていた。

examples.en: My mother in a weak voice told her grandmother, "Take time to rest."
examples.ja: 母は弱々しい声で、おばあちゃんに「ゆっくり、休んで」と言った。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is double <kanji>weak</kanji> is probably pretty weak. You also know that this is an adjective because it ends with い. You know that 弱い is weak, so it probably isn't that. Instead, this one is <vocabulary>weak looking</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>frail</vocabulary>. If you know the grammar らしい you can kind of use that as a hint. The しい on the end reminds me of らしい which is like "seems to be." So, "seems to be weak" = "weak looking."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is double kun'yomi, as you can probably guess due to all the hiragana involved. So, you double up on よわ and then add the しい to read this vocabulary word.

examples.en: The mouth of the mug is chipped.
examples.ja: マグカップの口の所が欠けてしまった。

examples.en: The moon was a little bit less than full last night.
examples.ja: 夕べの月、少しだけ欠けてましたね。

examples.en: My grandpa often says things that are rude and lacking in delicacy.
examples.ja: うちのおじいちゃんは、よくデリカシーに欠ける失礼な事を言います。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>lack</kanji>, and this verb has a few meanings related to that. You'll often see it meaning <vocabulary>to get chipped</vocabulary>, like when talking about a teacup or your teeth. I guess a chipped teacup is lacking... a piece of itself?

欠ける can also literally mean <vocabulary>to be lacking</vocabulary>, as in "a good goalie is lacking from their team." You can use it like this when you're short of something, or when something is missing that would complete a set. In these situations, you'll usually see it as 欠けている!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Something is lacking... it's a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only that car wasn't missing, this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because that car's not present.

examples.en: The height of that apartment is thirty meters.
examples.ja: あのアパートの高さは三十メートルです。

examples.en: I can never beat Koichi and Michael when it comes to their level of humor.
examples.ja: ギャグセンの高さでは、どうしてもコウイチとマイケルには勝てないよ。

examples.en: Mt. Fuji has not only height but also beauty.
examples.ja: ふじ山には、高さだけでなく、美しさもある。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word 高い from a couple levels ago. This word is related to that. It's like 大きい versus 大きさ, where one describes the other. In this case, the 高さ is the <vocabulary>height</vocabulary> of something (while 高い is tall). This word isn't "price" though. For that you'd ask いくらですか？ (how much is it?).
reading_mnemonic: Use the reading of 高い (たかい) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They're the same except for the hiragana at the end.

examples.en: Seventy years ago, TV was black and white.
examples.ja: 七十年前、テレビは白黒でした。

examples.en: Let’s put it in very black and white terms.
examples.ja: 白黒ハッキリつけようぜ。

examples.en: Kanae-chan, don't you look a bit like a panda in your black and white outfit today?
examples.ja: カナエちゃん、今日の全身白黒の服は、ちょっとパンダみたいじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: Something is both <kanji>white</kanji> and <kanji>black</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>black and white</vocabulary> (you can also say <vocabulary>white and black</vocabulary> if you prefer).
reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should have seen both 白 and 黒い separately as vocabulary by now. It's the same readings here, so you can apply that knowledge and read this word!

examples.en: Today is the day I return the car money to my father.
examples.ja: 今日は、父に車のお金を返す日です。

examples.en: I want to return your book. Are you home tomorrow?
examples.ja: 本を返したいんだけど、明日は家にいる？

examples.en: "Could you return the cookies I gave you yesterday?" "Huh? You mean, I should spit them up?"
examples.ja: 「昨日あげたクッキー返してくれない？」「えっ、口から出せってこと？」

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to return something</vocabulary>. 

This is more like "to return a thing" rather than returning home, which would be 帰る, a word you haven't seen yet (but will soon, I'm sure!).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> the <reading>Ca</reading>r <reading>e</reading>gg (かえ) you found on the side of the road. It will birth a little car, but it needs its mother. So, you try to figure out how to return it. Go ahead and think through that process in your mind. Also think about how weird a car egg would be.

examples.en: That's very nice footage.
examples.ja: すごくいい映像ですね。
