examples.en: Well, we can't show the little ones this video.
examples.ja: この映像は小さい子には見せられないね。

examples.en: Have you watched Michael's videos on YouTube yet?
examples.ja: YouTubeのマイケルの映像、もう見た？

examples.en: That video became a bit traumatic for me.
examples.ja: あの映像、ちょっとトラウマになっちゃいました。

examples.en: The story of that movie is mediocre, but the visuals are incredibly beautiful.
examples.ja: その映画、ストーリーはイマイチだけど、映像がめっちゃ美しいんですよ。

examples.en: Since I watched Ringu, I can't get the image of Sadako coming out of that old well out of my head.
examples.ja: 映画リングを見てからというもの、古イドからさだ子が出てくる映像がアタマからはなれないんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You see <kanji>reflect</kanji>ions of <kanji>image</kanji>s on a screen, and the image reflections are moving! That means this is <vocabulary>footage</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>video</vocabulary>.

映像 refers to <vocabulary>image</vocabulary>s in various forms of visual media. While it's most commonly used to describe moving images in videos or films, it can also refer to mental images — those pictures or scenes that come to mind, reflecting personal memories or imagination.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That's an interesting image.
examples.ja: おもしろい画像ですね。

examples.en: This image is a bit blurry, isn't it?
examples.ja: この画像、ちょっとぼやけてるね。

examples.en: I'll send you the image later!
examples.ja: あとで画像を送るよ！

examples.en: Where is the image data located?
examples.ja: 画像データはどこにありますか？

examples.en: I'm downloading the image now.
examples.ja: 今、画像をダウンロードしています。

examples.en: Don't use my picture without my permission!
examples.ja: 勝手にわたしの画像を使わないでくださいよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>image</kanji> of an <kanji>image</kanji> is still an <vocabulary>image</vocabulary>. This can also be a <vocabulary>picture</vocabulary>.

画像 can refer to all sorts of images and pictures, but these days it's mostly used for the digital kind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is important for the factory to maintain high quality.
examples.ja: 高いクオリティを保持するのは工場にとって大切なことです。

examples.en: I retained the US title this year too.
examples.ja: 今年も全米タイトルを保持しました。

examples.en: The data will be preserved for one month, then it will be gone.
examples.ja: データは一ヶ月保持された後は、全てなくなります。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>preserve</kanji> the things you <kanji>hold</kanji> on to, you're <vocabulary>keep</vocabulary>ing them. In other words, you're <vocabulary>hold</vocabulary>ing and <vocabulary>maintain</vocabulary>ing them!

Note that 保持 is a formal word that's commonly used in professional or official contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A life insurance sales manager came home earlier.
examples.ja: さっき生保のセールスマネジャーが家に来ましたよ。

examples.en: When the heck can I get the money from my deceased husband's life insurance?
examples.ja: 亡くなった主人の生保のお金は、一体いつもらえるんですか？

examples.en: If you buy life insurance, you will have peace of mind if anything ever happens to you.
examples.ja: 生保に入れば、万が一自分に何かあったとしても安心です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>Life</kanji> <kanji>guarantee</kanji> is something you get on someone else. If their life ends, it's guaranteed with money. That's a <vocabulary>life insurance</vocabulary> policy, for yah! (A.K.A. <vocabulary>life assurance</vocabulary> in some parts of the world!)
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: To keep your physical strength, you have to train every day.
examples.ja: 体力を保つには毎日トレーニングしなくてはいけません。

examples.en: I do yoga and meditation to maintain a healthy heart.
examples.ja: 元気な心を保つために、ヨガやメディテーションをします。

examples.en: I want to live a healthy life and maintain my current weight.
examples.ja: ヘルシーな生活を送って、今の体重を保ちたいと思います。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>preserve</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to preserve something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to keep something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to maintain something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You preserve something, like your youth.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you want to learn how <vocabulary>to preserve something</vocabulary> like fruits and veggies, you should start with <reading>tamots</reading> (たも), that's slang for delish tomatoes. Once they're preserved, you get to make everyone you love eat those yummy tamots. Mmm!

examples.en: Today, I will try this method.
examples.ja: 今日は、やり方を試みる。

examples.en: The female spy tried to get closer to the man at the bar.
examples.ja: 女スパイは、バーで男の人に近づくことを試みた。

examples.en: I decided to try a new approach.
examples.ja: 新しいアプローチを試みる事に決めました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>try</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to try to do something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to attempt something</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. Here, the direct object is whatever it is that you're trying to do.
reading_mnemonic: You know how when you try to do something you put your whole heart into it? Well, think of that in Japanese. You put your whole <reading>心</reading> (こころ) into it.

examples.en: First, just taste it without saying anything.
examples.ja: 先ずは何も言わないで試食してみて。

examples.en: I lost interest in buying this after sampling it.
examples.ja: 試食の後、買う気を失ったんです。

examples.en: It's almost like I'm going to Costco to eat the food samples.
examples.ja: コストコには試食のサンプルを食べるために行くようなものです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Go ahead and <kanji>try</kanji> an <kanji>eat</kanji>. How was that little try? That little <vocabulary>food sample</vocabulary>? That little <vocabulary>taste</vocabulary>?

You know when you walk into the supermarket and have people offering you the tiniest cube of cheese? That's what this is. So this word is commonly used in the context of product demonstrations or food events.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It was a wonderful experience to go backpacking abroad by myself.
examples.ja: 海外へ一人でバックパッキングに行ったのは、すばらしい体験でした。

examples.en: All of our staff had the once-in-a-lifetime experience of growing potatoes in Kyushu.
examples.ja: スタッフ全員、九州でじゃがいも作りと言う一生に一回の体験をしました。

examples.en: Doing an internship is like doing a trial run at the company.
examples.ja: インターンをするというのは、体験入社をするようなものです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>body</kanji> goes through <kanji>test</kanji>s and each time it does, it gains a little more <vocabulary>experience</vocabulary>. What has your body experienced? What tests has your body been through?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I study every day for university entrance exams.
examples.ja: 大学受験のために、毎日勉強しています。

examples.en: It was a year of great anxiety and stress about taking the exams.
examples.ja: 受験の不安とストレスが大きい一年でした。

examples.en: If my exams go well, they'll buy me a new game.
examples.ja: 受験がうまくいけば、新しいゲームを買ってもらえるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>accept</kanji> a <kanji>test</kanji> you are <vocabulary>taking an exam</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>taking a test</vocabulary>. Good luck! A++++!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is a science experiment.
examples.ja: これは科学の実験です。

examples.en: When conducting an experiment, be sure to wear a helmet for safety.
examples.ja: 実験を行う時は、安全のために必ずヘルメットをして下さい。

examples.en: Now, I'd like to try an experiment to see what I have to say to get my mother to give me money.
examples.ja: これから、お母さんは何と言ったらお金をくれるのか、実験したいと思います。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>test</kanji> that tries to find <kanji>truth</kanji> is an <vocabulary>experiment</vocabulary>. This is because you don't know the truth, so the only way to find it is to try things out and test them. Thus, experiment!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Take note that the つ in じつ is turned into a small っ, though.

examples.en: Oh, is the JLPT exam tomorrow? I just remembered.
examples.ja: あれ、JLPT試験、明日だっけ？今、思い出した。

examples.en: "By the way, how was the exam?" "Dad, be quiet."
examples.ja: 「ところで、試験はどうだった？」「パパ、しずかにして。」

examples.en: It's important for safety to do a lot of tests before many people use it.
examples.ja: 多くの人が使う前に、たくさん試験をすることが安全にとって重要です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>attempt</kanji> a <kanji>test</kanji>, you're taking an <vocabulary>examination</vocabulary>. There are a lot of these in Japan, so make sure you know this word if you want to fit in with all the whining and whinging that students do, especially come the final year of high school.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Japanese life and American life don't make for a good comparison.
examples.ja: 日本の生活とアメリカの生活じゃ、いい対比にならないよ。

examples.en: Now let's compare this fish with that one.
examples.ja: では、この魚とその魚を対比してみましょう。

examples.en: I compared Japanese and American movie posters.
examples.ja: 日本とアメリカの映画のポスターを対比してみました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you look at something <kanji>versus</kanji> something else, you <kanji>compare</kanji> them with one another. You look at the <vocabulary>contrast</vocabulary> between them and make a <vocabulary>comparison</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Now for the announcement. The winner of the speech contest is Mr. Tanaka!
examples.ja: それでは、発表します。スピーチコンテストの勝者は田中さんです！

examples.en: I participated in the university presentation conference.
examples.ja: 大学のプレゼンテーション発表会に参加しました。

examples.en: Apparently, the president wants to make a very important announcement for the company and the staff.
examples.ja: 社長が会社とスタッフにとって、とても大切な発表をしたいそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>express</kanji> my <kanji>departure</kanji>. That is my only <vocabulary>announcement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ひょう changes to ぴょう and the はつ gets shortened, though, so just about everything about this word is weird.

examples.en: The data shows everything.
examples.ja: データは全てを表す。

examples.en: This red ball is called "hinomaru," and represents the sunrise.
examples.ja: この赤い玉は、「日の丸」と言って、日の出を表しています。

examples.en: I made cookies to express my thanks to you, Sensei.
examples.ja: 先生へのお礼を表すために、クッキーを作ったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>express</kanji> and the verb vocab version is transitive, meaning that it's done to something. So this verb means <vocabulary>to express something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to show something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're struggling <vocabulary>to express something</vocabulary> to your friends: namely, that you <reading>are a wa</reading>lrus (あらわ). All your friends think you're a human, so they'll be shocked when you express to them the fact that, actually, you are a walrus. You need to get it off your chest though… Your big, blubbery walrus chest.

examples.en: There are five minutes until departure.
examples.ja: 出発まで五分です。

examples.en: I'm going to leave for Tokyo in two weeks.
examples.ja: 二週間後に、東京に出発する予定です。

examples.en: Let's have some tea until the ferry departs.
examples.ja: フェリーが出発するまでの時間、お茶でものみましょうよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> and then make a <kanji>departure</kanji>. This is just a <vocabulary>departure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゅつ gets shortened and はつ changes to ぱつ. No wonder you want to make a departure, you want to get away from crazy readings like this.

examples.en: "Omg! My mouth is on fire, but this curry is sooo good!"
examples.ja: 「やばい〜！めっちゃ辛い～！でも、このカレーすっげ〜美味しい！」

examples.en: I can't eat spicy food.
examples.ja: 私、辛いものは食べれないんです。

examples.en: Oh, that's what happened? That's tough.
examples.ja: え、そんなことがあったの？それは辛いね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. That being said, this can also mean <vocabulary>difficult</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary>, often in a psychological sense, though it can be physical as well. I guess if you're in a spicy situation it's going to be a difficult one.
reading_mnemonic:
Depending on the context, the reading for this word could be からい or つらい. 

The からい reading is the <vocabulary>spicy</vocabulary> one that you learned with the kanji, which you can remember because spicy foods give a <reading>から</reading>て chop to your mouth. 

The つらい reading is the <vocabulary>difficult</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> one. You can remember this because <reading>two Ra</reading>s (つら) are way more difficult to deal with than one Ra.

examples.en: When it comes to oden, Japanese mustard is a must, isn’t it?
examples.ja: やっぱりオデンには辛子でしょ。

examples.en: I only have Japanese mustard in tube form, but is that okay?
examples.ja: 辛子、チューブのやつしかないけどいい？

examples.en: Both Japanese mustard and Western mustard are made from the seeds of the same plant, mustard greens.
examples.ja: 辛子もマスタードも、同じカラシナのタネから作られます。

examples.en: Seeds from a type of mustard green called "Oriental mustard" are used for Japanese mustard, while yellow mustard seeds or brown mustard seeds are used for regular mustard.
examples.ja: 辛子に使われるのはオリエンタルマスタードというカラシナのタネ、マスタードに使われるのはイエローマスタードやブラウンマスタードというカラシナのタネです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>spicy</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is the child of spicy. So, not as spicy as mamma spicy, but still a bit spicy. This child spicy is <vocabulary>mustard</vocabulary>. Not too spicy, but not too mild.

辛子 generally refers to <vocabulary>Japanese mustard</vocabulary>, which tends to be browner and stronger than マスタード (Western mustard). Sometimes, especially as a prefix, it can also indicate spiciness from red pepper, like 辛子マヨネーズ (spicy mayo).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 辛い (からい) and the on'yomi reading for 子 combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.

examples.en: The other day, I went to the bookstore with a friend.
examples.ja: 先日、友人と本屋に行きました。

examples.en: Three days ago, I bought a book by a famous writer at the bookstore.
examples.ja: 三日前、本屋で有名な作家の本を買いました。

examples.en: I camped out in front of the bookstore a day early in order to buy a new book.
examples.ja: 私は新しい本を買うために、前の日から本屋の前でキャンプをしました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a shop that sells books. A <vocabulary>bookstore</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones that you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I'm going to buy all the apples.
examples.ja: リンゴを全部買うつもりです。

examples.en: I got good test scores in all subjects.
examples.ja: 全部の科目のテストで良いスコアでした。

examples.en: Who the hell ate all my bacon cookies?!
examples.ja: 私のベーコンクッキー全部食べたのは一体だれ！？

meaning_mnemonic: If you take <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s and put them together, you have <vocabulary>all</vocabulary> things. The <vocabulary>entire</vocabulary> collection. It is <vocabulary>whole</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The puppy was like an angel.
examples.ja: 子犬は天使みたいでした。

examples.en: What's charming about Koichi is his angelic smile.
examples.ja: コウイチ君は、天使のようなスマイルがチャームポイントです。

examples.en: Are you really an angel?
examples.ja: 本当に、あなた天使なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: One who <kanji>use</kanji>s <kanji>heaven</kanji> to their advantage is someone from heaven, like an <vocabulary>angel</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We will have a big sale in the new year.
examples.ja: 新年に大きいセールを行います。

examples.en: At the start of new year, many people set goals for that year.
examples.ja: 新年になると、多くの人が一年のゴールを立てます。

examples.en: In the new year, many people buy lottery tickets.
examples.ja: 新年は、宝くじを買う人が多いです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is a <vocabulary>new year</vocabulary>. Hope you had / have / are having a good one, depending on when you read this.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I need more time to think.
examples.ja: 考えるのに、もっと時間が要る。

examples.en: Do you need a bag?
examples.ja: ふくろは要りますか？

examples.en: This is a list of things you need and what you don't need.
examples.ja: これは要る物と要らない物のリストです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>need</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to need</vocabulary>.

This one's a little tricky, because although it's usually translated as "to need" in English, it's used more like <vocabulary>to be needed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be necessary</vocabulary>. That is, it's an intransitive verb in Japanese, so it doesn't take a direct object.
reading_mnemonic: Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going <vocabulary>to need</vocabulary>... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an <reading>ea</reading>gle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.

examples.en: I went to an event for discussions between engineering and psychology scholars.
examples.ja: 工学と心理学の学者の対談のイベントに行きました。

examples.en: Last week, a discussion was held between a famous writer and a genius modern artist.
examples.ja: 先週、有名な作家と天才モダンアーティストとの対談が行われました。

examples.en: This month's issue should have my interview.
examples.ja: 今月号には、私の対談がのってるはずです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is when you sit down with another person and have a <vocabulary>talk</vocabulary>. As you're talking, it might evolve into a <vocabulary>discussion</vocabulary>. Or perhaps you're there to have an <vocabulary>interview</vocabulary>.

対談 is usually a formal discussion between two or more individuals, often organized ahead of time, and with a specific purpose or topic in mind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please take a look at this part.
examples.ja: この部分を見て下さい。

examples.en: A part of the water supply has stopped due to the typhoon.
examples.ja: 台風の影響で、水道の一部分が止まっています。

examples.en: Is it okay to use this one section from the video?
examples.ja: ビデオのこの一部分だけ使ってもいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Part</kanji> of a <kanji>part</kanji>? That's a <vocabulary>portion</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>section</vocabulary> of that part, and even a <vocabulary>part</vocabulary> in itself!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

examples.en: My mother has a leg disability, so she often uses a car.
examples.ja: 母は足が不自由なので、車を使うことが多いです。

examples.en: This is a bench for grandpas, grandmas, and people with physical disabilities.
examples.ja: ここは、おじいちゃん・おばあちゃん、体の不自由な方のためのベンチです。

examples.en: Every citizen should help out to support those who live life with disabilities.
examples.ja: 不自由な生活を送っている人々をサポートするために、国民全員が助力するべきです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 自由 means freedom? Well when you add <kanji>not</kanji> it causes you <vocabulary>discomfort</vocabulary> and really <vocabulary>inconveniences</vocabulary> you. That not is in the way of your freedom.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Living every day to your fullest" is a teaching from my father.
examples.ja: 「毎日全力で生きる」というのは、父からの教えです。

examples.en: It's such a great lesson, isn't it?
examples.ja: それは、すばらしい教えですね。

examples.en: My child has not been taught enough about manners, and I apologize if they have been rude.
examples.ja: うちの子は、マナーに対する教えが足りず、失礼なことがあったらすみません。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>teach</kanji>. So it means <vocabulary>teaching</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 教える, so you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: Please paint the front of this paper pink.
examples.ja: この紙の表はピンク色にぬってください。

examples.en: Which side of a ten yen coin is the front?
examples.ja: 十円玉コインの表はどちらですか？

examples.en: Koichi is the president of Tofugu. Officially speaking, anyway.
examples.ja: コウイチは、トーフグの社長です。表向きは。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 表 meant both <kanji>express</kanji> and <kanji>surface</kanji>? This expands on the second meaning, making this <vocabulary>the front</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the surface</vocabulary>. 

表 refers to the visible, outward-facing side of something, in contrast to the hidden, back side. It's used for surfaces on display, like the front of a building, the face of a coin, the cover of a book, or the top surface of a package.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're standing there, staring at <vocabulary>the front</vocabulary> of this building. You spend some time gazing at it before you realize what it is. "<reading>Oh</reading>, <reading>mote</reading>l (おもて)," you say aloud. <vocabulary>The surface</vocabulary> of this building really gave it away. "Oh, motel!"

examples.en: Does this neighborhood have a convenience store?
examples.ja: この付近に、コンビニはありますか？

examples.en: A doctor nearby helped me.
examples.ja: 付近にいた医者が助けてくれました。

examples.en: Please be careful of snakes near the mountains.
examples.ja: 山の付近ではヘビに気をつけて下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>attach</kanji> things <kanji>near</kanji> you, they end up being in the same <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary> as you. They're attached <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary> so they can't go much further.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 付 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary> is full of <reading>foo</reading>ls (ふ). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary>.

examples.en: This song is a masterpiece that I remember many times a year.
examples.ja: この曲は一年に何度も思い出す名曲です。

examples.en: I have ordered the same thing at the same restaurant many times.
examples.ja: 同じレストランで同じものをオーダーしたことが何度もあります。

examples.en: I wrote a fan letter many times, but I didn't get a reply.
examples.ja: 何度もファンレターを出したけど、中々返事が来ない。

meaning_mnemonic: If someone asks you <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> or <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s they're really trying to ask you <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary> something happened. Sometimes they're asking <vocabulary>what temperature</vocabulary> it is too.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: Michael's swimming is better than the fish's!
examples.ja: マイケルは魚よりも泳ぎが上手です。

examples.en: I want a professional instructor to correct my swimming form.
examples.ja: プロの先生に泳ぎのフォームを正してほしいです。

examples.en: It was a wonderful swim.
examples.ja: すばらしい泳ぎでしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>swim</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>swimming</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: The author of this article is an American journalist.
examples.ja: この記事の作者は、アメリカ人ジャーナリストです。

examples.en: There are not many articles about diplomacy.
examples.ja: 外交についての記事があまりない。

examples.en: The articles from this month's issue are full of nonsense.
examples.ja: 今月号の記事はデタラメばっかりだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>write down</kanji> a lot of stuff focusing on one <kanji>thing</kanji> it's called an <vocabulary>article</vocabulary>. If it's on something that just happened it will probably be a <vocabulary>news story</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Fire!!
examples.ja: 火事だ！！

examples.en: Please be careful with lit cigarettes so as not to cause a fire.
examples.ja: 火事にならないよう、タバコの火には気をつけて下さいね。

examples.en: It seems there was a fire at 3-chome yesterday. There were no deaths or injuries.
examples.ja: 昨日、３丁目で火事があったそうです。死者やケガ人は出ませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>matter</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fire</vocabulary>, as in the destructive burning of something. There's a fire! Run, run away!

火事 is often used for when houses or other buildings are on fire. If you hear someone shout 火事だ, it's probably time to get out of wherever you are.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Glass lets light pass through it.
examples.ja: ガラスは光を通します。

examples.en: Please heat the meat thoroughly.
examples.ja: お肉には、しっかり火を通してください。

examples.en: Never let others who you just met into your home.
examples.ja: 会ったばかりの他人を家に通しちゃダメです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 通る means to pass, but this is a little different. You aren't the one passing, Sue (す) is. So you have to let Sue pass. In other words, this verb is transitive, meaning it has an object. That's why it means <vocabulary>to let something pass</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put something through</vocabulary>.

The way this verb is translated into English changes a lot depending on the noun it's paired with. For example 火を通す is literally "to let the fire pass through", and means "to heat through". 針に糸を通す is literally "to put thread through a needle", so means "to thread a needle".
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 通る. Switch the る for a す and you'll be all set!

examples.en: There are various creatures in the sea.
examples.ja: 海の中には、色々な生物がいます。

examples.en: I wonder what that creature was.
examples.ja: あの生物は一体何だったんでしょう。

examples.en: I'm wondering if you can show me your notes from the last biology class.
examples.ja: 前回の生物のクラスのノート、見せてくれないかな。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>life</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is a <vocabulary>living thing</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>creature</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>organism</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The housekeepers take care of most of the housework.
examples.ja: 大体の家事はハウスキーパーの方がしてくれます。

examples.en: I think I don't have enough time to watch TV due to the house chores.
examples.ja: 家事のせいで、テレビを見る時間が不足していると思っています。

examples.en: Housework is not my innate forte, so it takes me some time every day.
examples.ja: 元々私は家事に向いてないので、毎日時間がかかってしまいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You know 事 means "occurrence," but it also means "matter." So you can think of a <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>matter</kanji> as  as <vocabulary>housework</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>chores</vocabulary>. Housework and chores are really just house matters that you have to deal with, after all.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of 家 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Housework</vocabulary> done in a <reading>car</reading> (か) is still housework. Think of all the times you've tidied up your car. That's housework too!

examples.en: There were many amulets at the entrance of the village.
examples.ja: 村の入り口にお札がたくさんありました。

examples.en: You should be careful not to show your hand.
examples.ja: 自分の札を見せないようにした方がいいよ。

examples.en: I didn't knock because the vacant room tag was hung.
examples.ja: 空室の札がかかってたので、ノックしなかったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word is almost the same as the kanji, but only half of it. It means <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary>. They're about the same shape and size as money, but you can't buy a house with them (...probably).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You can't find your <vocabulary>tag</vocabulary> anywhere. It was just there, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You search for it everywhere, then you realize... it was right there all along. Seriously? You're such a <reading>foo</reading>l, <reading>duh</reading> (ふだ)!

examples.en: Excuse me. I don't know how to use this coupon.
examples.ja: すみません。このクーポンの使用の仕方が分からないんです。

examples.en: Do you know how much water is used in a pool?
examples.ja: プールにどれくらいの水を使用か知ってますか？

examples.en: We use new biology technology that utilizes insects.
examples.ja: 虫を利用した新しい生物学テクノロジーを使用しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something you <kanji>use</kanji> that has a <kanji>use</kanji> has... well, <vocabulary>use</vocabulary>. You can even use it for practical <vocabulary>application</vocabulary>s.

使用 has a slightly more formal tone compared to 使う, and it’s preferred in situations that require a more precise and less casual choice of words.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I buy curry, I always buy the spicy kind.
examples.ja: カレーはいつも辛口を買います。

examples.en: Asahi Super Dry is a dry beer that has a sharp, crisp feeling when it goes down your throat.
examples.ja: アサヒスーパードライはシャープなのどごしの辛口ビールです。

examples.en: Everyone gave harsh opinions, but I am actually a big fan of this drama.
examples.ja: みんなは辛口コメントだったけど、私はこのドラマの大ファンです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you put something <kanji>spicy</kanji> in your <kanji>mouth</kanji> you'll end up with a <vocabulary>spicy taste</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>dry taste</vocabulary> in there. Spice sucks up all your mouth moistness.
reading_mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi readings together. You should have learned them both by now.

examples.en: I'm from Malaysia.
examples.ja: 私はマレーシア出身です。

examples.en: I'm from Aomori, so I don't know the Kyushu dialect.
examples.ja: 青森出身なので、九州の方言は分かりません。

examples.en: The author of this book is from the same place as me.
examples.ja: この本の作者は私と同じ場所の出身なんです。

examples.en: Where is your husband from?
examples.ja: あなたのご主人はどこの出身なんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>exit</kanji> that <kanji>somebody</kanji> starts from is <vocabulary>one's origin</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>one's hometown</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>one's birthplace</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the つ of 出, which becomes っ.

examples.en: In many sports, such as rugby, there are rules for substitution.
examples.ja: ラグビーなど、多くのスポーツで交代のルールがあります。

examples.en: My father and mother take turns making dinner every day.
examples.ja: 父と母は毎日交代で夜ごはんを作ります。

examples.en: The other day, there was a change of company president for the first time in sixteen years.
examples.ja: 先日、十六年ぶりに社長交代がありました。

examples.en: Could you switch in for me soon?
examples.ja: そろそろ交代してもらえませんか？

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>mix</kanji> and <kanji>substitute</kanji> two people, that's a <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> of personnel, or a <vocabulary>substitution</vocabulary>. Perhaps those people are even working in <vocabulary>shift</vocabulary>s, so they mix and substitute each other at regular intervals.

You'll see this word in pretty diverse contexts, because it can refer to anything from a change of political regime, to the substitution of a player during a match, to factory shifts. The underlying meaning is that one person or group is switched out with another.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

A <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> calls for a <reading>tie</reading> (たい). If you're the new company president, or you're going in to work to start your shift, you'd better make sure you look the part, so get that tie nice and straight.

examples.en: This is my karate teacher, Jeff-sensei.
examples.ja: こちらは私の空手の先生、ジェフ先生です。

examples.en: I want to do karate at university too.
examples.ja: 大学でも空手をやりたいと思ってます。

examples.en: There's apparently a new karate dojo at the nearby sports center.
examples.ja: 近くのスポーツセンターに、新しく空手の道場ができたそうですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: What can you do with <kanji>empty</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji>s? <vocabulary>Karate</vocabulary>, that's what. Karate is practiced without weapons, so with empty hands!
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji, and you haven't learned this kun'yomi for 空 yet. As long as you know the meaning, the reading should be easy, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

<vocabulary>Karate</vocabulary> comes from (<reading>から</reading>) Japan!

examples.en: This hotel was originally an apartment.
examples.ja: このホテルは元々アパートだったんです。

examples.en: That model used to be a designer, right?
examples.ja: あのモデルさんって、元々はデザイナーだったんでしょ？

examples.en: This house originally had a bathroom and kitchen in it.
examples.ja: 元々この家にはトイレもキッチンもあったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
It's the <kanji>origin</kanji> of all <kanji>origin</kanji>s, so it's the way it was <vocabulary>originally</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>from the beginning</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>by nature</vocabulary>. You get the idea.

Note that this is frequently written in just hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version too!
reading_mnemonic: This is just the kun'yomi reading you learned with 元, but twice, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: This is heartening data!
examples.ja: これは心強いデータですね！

examples.en: It's reassuring to have a professional player as my partner.
examples.ja: プロのプレイヤーがパートナーになってくれるなんて、心強いです。

examples.en: The teacher's advice became a reassuring support for our students.
examples.ja: 先生の助言は、私たち学生にとって心強いサポートとなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: Things that make your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>strong</kanji> are <vocabulary>reassuring</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>heartening</vocabulary> to hear. You can practically feel your heart becoming stronger in your chest.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words 心 and 強い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that つよい gets rendaku'd to づよい!

examples.en: I've played almost all of the games here.
examples.ja: ここにあるゲーム、ほとんどプレイしたことあるよ。

examples.en: I hardly understand any of this lecture.
examples.ja: このレクチャー、ほとんど分からないんだけど。

examples.en: Most people have smartphones nowadays.
examples.ja: 今どき、スマホなんてほとんどの人がもってるでしょ。

meaning_mnemonic: What can be eaten <reading>hot on dough</reading> (ほとんど)? <vocabulary>Most</vocabulary> things can. <vocabulary>Almost all</vocabulary> things, in fact. <vocabulary>Hardly</vocabulary> anything tastes bad when it's hot and served on dough.

examples.en: Is this pen made of glass?
examples.ja: このペン、ガラスで出来てるの？

examples.en: Wow, it looks like Cinderella's glass slipper.
examples.ja: うわー、シンデレラのガラスのくつみたい。

examples.en: You have bird poop on your windshield.
examples.ja: フロントガラスに鳥のフンが付いてるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This comes from the word <vocabulary>glass</vocabulary>, and it refers to the stuff used to make Cinderella's slippers, and windows, in which case it can also mean a <vocabulary>pane of glass</vocabulary>.

We'll learn how to say the other meanings of "glass" later!

examples.en: I met my teacher there.
examples.ja: そこで先生に会ったよ。

examples.en: If you're looking for snacks, they're there.
examples.ja: おやつなら、そこにあるよ。

examples.en: You don't have to say so much!
examples.ja: そこまで言わなくてもいいじゃない！

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how words beginning with そ are either close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you? And how words ending in こ refer to places? This one's no exception. そこ means <vocabulary>there</vocabulary>.

examples.en: My house is over there.
examples.ja: 私のうちは、あそこだよ。

examples.en: Let's take a short rest over there!
examples.ja: あそこでちょっと休もう！

examples.en: What's that thing over there?
examples.ja: あそこにあるのは何？

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how words beginning with あ show that whatever you're talking about is far away from both you and the person you're talking to? And how words ending in こ refer to places? So what do you think this means? That right, it's <vocabulary>over there</vocabulary>.

Note that even though あそこ means "over there," it's still used to refer to a specific, concrete place, as opposed to a word like 向こう which means "over there" in a broader, more general sense.

examples.en: I lost five kilos in one month.
examples.ja: 一ヶ月で五キロやせました。

examples.en: It is roughly 3 km from our house to the school.
examples.ja: うちから学校まで、大体３キロです。

examples.en: This stone sells for only one yen per kilo.
examples.ja: この石は、キロ当たり１円にしかなりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
キロ comes from <vocabulary>kilo</vocabulary>, and it can mean <vocabulary>kilogram</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>kilometer</vocabulary>, or any unit that starts with "kilo" in English.

You can also use abbreviations like "kg" and "km" in Japanese, and they're often just pronounced キロ too.

examples.en: In this house, the father is in a weak position.
examples.ja: この家では父が弱い立場にいます。

examples.en: I'm not in a position to say such things.
examples.ja: 私はそんなこと言える立場じゃありません。

examples.en: From a user's standpoint, this app is hard to use.
examples.ja: ユーザーの立場から言うと、このアプリは使いにくいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>stand</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is where you stand. In other words, it's your <vocabulary>standpoint</vocabulary>, like in a discussion or on an issue. 

While 立場 can mean a literal standing place, it's almost always used metaphorically — to describe your stance in an argument or the complexities of your <vocabulary>position</vocabulary> within society, a situation, or a relationship.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. 立 comes from 立ち (the noun form of 立つ), and you learned the kun'yomi reading for 場 with 場所. But here's a mnemonic for both in case you need a refresher:

A sheep is trying to give you its <vocabulary>standpoint</vocabulary> on a <reading>touchy</reading> (たち) subject, but all it can do is say "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば). You're starting to get really offended that it's not baa-thering to take a more nuanced standpoint on such a touchy issue!

examples.en: After that, we just go back down the way we came.
examples.ja: あとはそのまま来た道を下るだけだ。

examples.en: A man riding a skateboard zoomed down the mountain.
examples.ja: スケボーに乗った男が山を下っていった。

examples.en: In Japan, there is a concept of referring to going north as "ascending" and going south as "descending."
examples.ja: 日本では、北に行くことを「上る」、南に行くことを「下る」と言うことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>below</kanji>, so you can guess the direction this movement verb takes: this is <vocabulary>to descend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary>.

As a movement verb, it usually describes a gradual downward movement. For example, you'd use this verb to describe walking down a mountain, driving down a hill, or going down a river in a boat.
reading_mnemonic: This verb uses the exceptional reading that 下さい also uses. So just replace the さい with る and you're good to go!

examples.en: Is there a way to receive a pension from overseas?
examples.ja: 海外から年金を受け取る方法ってありますか？

examples.en: I haven't received my ticket yet, even though I'm leaving tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日出発なのにまだチケットを受け取ってないんです。

examples.en: Since I'm at home, I'll receive the Amazon package on your behalf.
examples.ja: 家にいるから、アマゾンのパッケージ、代わりに受け取っておくよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 受ける means "to receive something." Combine it with 取る (to take something), and 受け取る… still means <vocabulary>to receive something</vocabulary>.

However, while 受ける generally implies passive reception, 受け取る carries a stronger connotation of actively taking possession of something. It is used when receiving a package or gift, or even when interpreting someone's words as having a specific meaning, such as an insult or compliment.
reading_mnemonic: If you know how to read 受ける and 取る, you should be good to go.

examples.en: It's one more month until Christmas!
examples.ja: クリスマスまであと一ヶ月ですね！

examples.en: I'll be going to school in Japan for one and a half months.
examples.ja: 一ヶ月半、日本で学校に行くんです。

examples.en: I played games at home without going outside for a month.
examples.ja: 一ヶ月間、家から出ずにゲームをした。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember the 〜ヶ月 counter? Replace the 〜 with a <kanji>one</kanji> and this becomes <vocabulary>one month</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: 一 uses the on'yomi you learned with it, but gets shortened, so watch out for that. The rest is as you learned it!

examples.en: Japanese schools only have one month of summer vacation.
examples.ja: 日本の学校の夏休みは一ヶ月しかありません。

examples.en: It took several months to complete this.
examples.ja: これが出来上がるまでに数ヶ月かかりました。

examples.en: How many months old is the baby?
examples.ja: 赤ちゃん、今何ヶ月ですか？

examples.en: My child started crawling at eight months and began walking at nine months.
examples.ja: うちの子は八ヶ月でハイハイをして、九ヶ月で歩き出しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Alright, so this one's a bit weird. See that oddly small ヶ there? Well, together with 月 (<kanji>month</kanji>), it becomes a <vocabulary>counter for months</vocabulary>. You'll use this when you want to talk about a specific number of months, so not when you're saying January, February, etc.

Note that you'll run into different variants of this. While 一ヶ月 is the most common, you'll also encounter 一か月, 一カ月, and rarely 一箇月. Luckily, they're all read the same, just written differently. Speaking about reading, let's get to it.
reading_mnemonic: The little ヶ might be slightly misleading, as you'll have to read this as か. The rest is easy though, as 月 just takes a normal on'yomi reading. And since we're not talking about specific months, that means it's just げつ, making this 〜かげつ.

examples.en: Let's rest here for ten minutes.
examples.ja: ここで十分間休みましょう。

examples.en: Can I play a game just for ten minutes?
examples.ja: 十分間だけゲームしていい？

examples.en: I think I can do it if I have ten minutes.
examples.ja: 十分間あれば出来ると思いますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've got a <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>minute</kanji> <kanji>interval of time</kanji>. That simply makes this <vocabulary>ten minutes</vocabulary>.

Note that, as we mentioned on the page for 〜間, you can omit 間 and this will still mean <vocabulary>ten minutes</vocabulary>! You'll especially see this in conversations and more casual contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You do know all of those, but their behaviour is a little different here. 十 (じゅう) and 分 (～ふん) together actually turn into じゅっぷん here. This is sometimes the case when using ～分 to mean "minute" in combination with certain numbers, so try to pay attention to this!

examples.en: Tropical countries are warm all year round.
examples.ja: 南国は一年中あたたかいです。

examples.en: I was born in a tropical country.
examples.ja: 私は南国で生まれました。

examples.en: Fruits in southern regions are very sweet.
examples.ja: 南国のフルーツはとてもあまいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you go far enough <kanji>south</kanji>, every <kanji>country</kanji> is a <vocabulary>tropical country</vocabulary>. Well, relative to Japan anyway… Probably different if you live in the southern hemisphere. 

In Japanese, 南国 often refers to tropical countries or islands like Thailand, Guam, and Hawaii. Sometimes it can refer to the warmer southern regions of Japan as well, like Okinawa.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings for 南 (なん) and 国 (こく, but rendaku'd to ごく here). You've seen those readings before, but the なん reading is still pretty new, so here's a mnemonic just in case:

When you're in a <vocabulary>tropical country</vocabulary>, you always get a craving for <reading>naan</reading> (なん) bread. You could be in any <vocabulary>southern country</vocabulary> with a warm, tropical climate — for some reason the heat just makes you want to nosh on some naan.

examples.en: A warm southerly wind is blowing.
examples.ja: あたたかい南風がふいています。

examples.en: The flowers are swaying in the south wind.
examples.ja: 南風で花がゆれています。

examples.en: The south wind feels nice today.
examples.ja: 今日は南風が気もちいいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>south</kanji> <kanji>wind</kanji> is… a <vocabulary>south wind</vocabulary>!

南風 is a wind that blows from the south. In Japan it's associated with the warmer temperatures it carries up from the tropics.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've seen before. The かぜ reading is the same one you learned with the vocab word 風, so if you can remember that you should have no trouble with this word!
